case_name: Provat Kumar Mitter v. Income-tax Officer

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 366 of 1959 is before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 366 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated September 18, 1958, of the Calcutta High Court in Income Tax Reference No. 9 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 18, 1958, of the Calcutta High Court in Income Tax Reference No. 9 of 1955.

facts.text: The assessee, Provat Kumar Mitter, is the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee, Provat Kumar Mitter, is the appellant before us.

facts.text: Provat Kumar Mitter was a registered holder of 500 Ordinary shares of the Calcutta Agency Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: He was a registered holder of 500 Ordinary shares. of the Calcutta Agency Ltd.

facts.text: By a written instrument dated January 19, 1953, Provat Kumar Mitter assigned to his wife, Ena Mitter, the right, title and interest to all dividends and sums of money on those shares for the term of her natural life.

anchor.surface_text: By a written instrument, dated January 19, 1953, he assigned to his wife, Ena Mitter, the right, title and interest to all dividends and sums of money which might be declared or might become due on account or in respect of those shares for the term of her natural life.

facts.text: The shares themselves remained the property of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: It is to be numbericed that under the terms quoted above the shares themselves remained the property of the assessee,

facts.text: During the accounting year which ended on March 31, 1953, the dividend declared on the shares amounted to Rs. 12,000.

anchor.surface_text: During the accounting year which ended on March 31, 1953, the dividend declared on the shares amounted to Rs. 12,000.

facts.text: In assessing the assessee for the assessment year 1953-54, the Income-tax Officer included Rs. 12,000 in his income under s. 16(1)(c) and s. 16(3).

anchor.surface_text: In assessing the as- sessee for the assessment year 1953-54 the Income-tax Officer included the said sum of Rs. 12,000 in his income under the provisions of s. 16 1  c  and s. 16 3  of the Act,

facts.text: Assessee contended that third proviso to s. 16(1)(c) applied since settlement for lifetime of wife.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the assessee was that since the settlement was for the lifetime of his wife, the third proviso to s. 16 1  c  applied

facts.text: Assessee contended s. 16(3) did not apply as no transfer of shares.

anchor.surface_text: and the dividend which his wife received companyld number be deemed to be his income under s. 16 1  c  as to s. 16 3  of the Act the assessee companytended that it did number apply, because there was numbertransfer of the shares to his wife.

facts.text: Assessee appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee, accordingly, appealed to the Appellate Assistant Com- missioner.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner dismissed the appeal accepting Department's contentions.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner accepted both the aforesaid companytentions and dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Further appeal to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: In a further appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal,

facts.text: Tribunal held the deed invalid as unregistered instrument.

anchor.surface_text: It gave effect, however, to the third companytention of the Department, namely, that the deed being an unregistered instrument did number operate as a valid transfer of the dividend income

facts.text: Tribunal referred three questions to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal acceded to the request and referred three questions to the High Court, two at the instance of the Commissioner and one at the instance of the assessee.

facts.text: High Court answered first two questions in favour of assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the first two questions in favour of the assessee.

facts.text: High Court answered third question against assessee.

anchor.surface_text: It answered the third question, however, against the assessee and in favour of the Department.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court on certificate under s.66A(2).

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal on a certificate of fitness granted by the High Court of Calcutta under s. 66A 2  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 8, 1960 by K. DAS, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. December 8. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by. K. DAS, J.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal limited to third question.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal before us is limited to the question of the companyrectness or otherwise of the answer given by the High Court to the third question.

facts.text: Department contended deed void as unregistered.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the deed dated January 19, 1953, assigning the dividends to accrue, merely on account of natural love and affection, is void as it is number registered?

facts.text: Supreme Court held the instrument was a contract to transfer future dividends, not transfer of existing property.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear to us that the instrument of January 19, 1953, was number a transfer of any existing property of the assessee. It was in its true nature a companytract to transfer or make over in future every dividend

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld High Court's answer on third question.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, companye to the companyclusion that the High Court companyrectly answered the question referred to it.
under s. 66A 2  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

issues.text: Whether the deed dated January 19, 1953, assigning the dividends to accrue, merely on account of natural love and affection, is void as it is number registered?

issues.text: Whether the third proviso to section 16 1  c  is repugnant to the main clause 16 1  c  and the general scheme of the Act, and should number be given effect to?

issues.text: Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the payment of dividend income to the assessees wife, Ena Mitter, under the companyenant in the deed of assignment dated January 19, 1953, was merely a case of application of the assessees income?

arguments.claim: High Court correctly answered the third question

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, come to the conclusion that the High Court correctly answered the question referred to it.

holdings.text: We must, therefore, overrule this contention.

anchor.surface_text: No objection appears to have been taken in the High Court to the reference made by the Tribunal on the three questions including the one now under consideration before us. In these circumstances it is not open to the appellant to contend now that the question did not arise out of the Tribunals order. We must, therefore, overrule this contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Question raised by Department and decided by implication in Tribunal order; no objection raised in High Court, so waived.

holdings.text: It is clear to us that the instrument of January 19, 1953, was not a transfer of any existing property of the assessee. It was in its true nature a contract to transfer or make over in future every dividend and sum of money which may be declared or become due and payable on account or in respect of the shares held by the assessee, to his wife during her lifetime the other covenants are ancillary in nature and subserve this main object of the contract.

anchor.surface_text: A transfer of property may take place not only in the present, but also in future but the property must be in existence. It is clear to us that the instrument of January 19, 1953, was not a transfer of any existing property of the assessee. It was in its true nature a contract to transfer or make over in future every dividend

holdings.reasoning_summary: Transfer requires existing property; dividends are future, so instrument creates contractual obligation to pay over future income.

holdings.text: The High Court rightly pointed out that the Company paying the dividend can pay it only to the registered shareholder or under his orders therefore, s. 16(1)(c) of the Income-tax Act was not attracted nor the third proviso thereto, and the income continued to accrue to the assessee but was thereafter paid over to his wife under the terms of the contract.

anchor.surface_text: If this is the true construction of the document, then it is clear to us that the answer given by the High Court to the question referred to it is correct. The High Court rightly pointed out that the Company paying the dividend can pay it only to the registered shareholder or under his orders  see Howrah Trading Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Central, Calcutta   1  therefore, s. 16 1  c  of the Income-tax Act was not attracted

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dividend payable only to registered holder; no transfer under s.16(1)(c), so proviso inapplicable; income accrues to assessee.

holdings.text: The income was, therefore, assessable in the hands of the assessee, because it was part of his income though applied subsequently towards payment to the wife under the terms of the contract.

anchor.surface_text: therefore, s. 16 1  c  of the Income-tax Act was number attracted number the third proviso thereto, and the income continued to accrue to the assessee but was thereafter paid over to his wife under the terms of the companytract. The income was, therefore, assessable in the hands of the assessee, because it was part of his income though applied subsequently towards payment to the wife under the terms of the companytract.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Income from shares accrues to assessee; payment to wife is subsequent application under contract.

holdings.text: We think that the true position is that if a person has alienated or assigned the source of his income so that it is no longer his, he may not be taxed upon the income arising after the assignment of the source, apart from special statutory provisions like s. 16(1)(c) or s. 16(3) which artificially deem it to be the assignors income. But if the assessee merely applies the income so that it passes through him and goes on to an ultimate purpose, even though he may have entered into a legal obligation to apply it in that way, it remains his income.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter, it is not necessary to decide the further question if a contract of this nature operates only as a contract to be performed in future which may be specifically enforced as soon as the property comes into existence or is a contract which fastens upon the property as soon as the settlor acquires it. In either view, the income from the shares will first accrue to the settlor before the beneficiary can get it. Such income will undoubtedly be assessable in the hands of the settlor despite the contract. We think that the true position is that if a person has alienated or assigned the source of his income so that it is no longer his,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes true alienation of source (not taxable absent deeming) from mere application/obligation to pay over (taxable).

holdings.text: We need only add that the principle laid down by the Privy Council in Bejoy Singh Dudhuria v. Commissioner of Income- tax , does not apply to this case because this is not a case of an allocation of a sum out of revenue before it becomes income in the hands of the assessee. In other words, this is not a case of diversion of income before it accrues but of application of income after it accrues.

anchor.surface_text: But if the assessee merely applies the income so that it passes through him and goes on to an ultimate purpose, even though he may have entered into a legal obligation to apply it in that way, it remains his income. This is exactly what has happened in the present case. We need only add that the principle laid down by the Privy Council in Bejoy Singh Dudhuria v. Commissioner of Income- tax  3 , does not apply to this case because this is not a case of an allocation of a sum out of revenue before it becomes income

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bejoy Singh applies to pre-accrual diversion/allocation; here post-accrual application.

holdings.text: We have, therefore, come to the conclusion that the High Court correctly answered the question referred to it.

anchor.surface_text: in the hands of the assessee. In other words, this is not a case of diversion of income before it accrues but of application of income after it accrues. We have, therefore, come to the conclusion that the High Court correctly answered the question referred to it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds High Court's view on third question as correct based on construction and application of law.

holdings.text: we are not concerned with the correctness or otherwise of the answers given by the High Court to those questions and we express no opinion as respects those answers.

anchor.surface_text: The first two questions having been answered in favour of the assessee and the Department not having filed any appeal with regard to them, we are not concerned with the correctness or otherwise of the answers given by the High Court to those questions and we express no opinion as respects those answers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No appeal by Department on first two questions answered for assessee.

holdings.text: we are not concerned with the correctness or otherwise of the answers given by the High Court to those questions and we express no opinion as respects those answers.

anchor.surface_text: The first two questions having been answered in favour of the assessee and the Department not having filed any appeal with regard to them, we are not concerned with the correctness or otherwise of the answers given by the High Court to those questions and we express no opinion as respects those answers.

precedents.citation: Bacha F. Guzdar Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay  1  at p. 883.

anchor.surface_text: In support of his companytention learned companynsel has relied on certain observations made by this Court in Bacha F. Guzdar Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay  1  at p. 883. , That was a case in which the question that arose for decision was whether dividend declared by a, companypany growing and manufacturing tea was agricultural income within the meaning of s. 2 1  of the Income-tax Act

precedents.case_name: Bacha F. Guzdar v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: shareholder's right to participate in the profits of the company exists independently of any declaration of dividend by the company
precedents.cited_holding: the right to participate in the profits exists independently of any declaration by the company with the only difference that the enjoyment of profits is postponed until dividends are declared

Commissioner of Income-tax, Central, Calcutta   1  therefore, s. 16 1  c  of the Income-tax Act was number attracted number the third proviso thereto, and the income companytinued to accrue to the assessee but was thereafter paid over to his wife under the terms of the companytract.

precedents.case_name: Howrah Trading Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Central, Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: a company paying dividend can pay it only to the registered shareholder or under his orders

precedents.citation: Bejoy Singh Dudhuria v. Commissioner of Income- tax  3

anchor.surface_text: We need only add that the principle laid down by the Privy Council in Bejoy Singh Dudhuria v. Commissioner of Income- tax  3 , does number apply to this case because this is number a case of an allocation of a sum out of revenue before it becomes income in the hands of the assessee. In other words, this is number a case of diversion of income before it accrues but of application of income after it accrues.

precedents.case_name: Bejoy Singh Dudhuria v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: principle distinguishing allocation of revenue before it becomes income (diversion) from application of income after accrual

anchor.surface_text: No objection appears to have been taken in the High Court to the reference made by the Tribunal on the three questions including the one now under consideration before us. In these circumstances it is not open to the appellant to contend now that the question did not arise out of the Tribunals order. We must, therefore, overrule this contention.
We have, therefore, come to the conclusion that the High Court correctly answered the question referred to it.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter, it is not necessary to decide the further question if a contract of this nature operates only as a contract to be performed in future which may be specifically enforced as soon as the property comes into existence or is a contract which fastens upon the property as soon as the settlor acquires it. In either view, the income from the shares will first accrue to the settlor before the beneficiary can get it. Such income will undoubtedly be assessable in the hands of the settlor despite the contract. We think that the true position is that if a person has alienated or assigned the source of his income so that it is no longer his,
We have, therefore, come to the conclusion that the High Court correctly answered the question referred to it.

anchor.surface_text: But if the assessee merely applies the income so that it passes through him and goes on to an ultimate purpose, even though he may have entered into a legal obligation to apply it in that way, it remains his income. This is exactly what has happened in the present case. We need only add that the principle laid down by the Privy Council in Bejoy Singh Dudhuria v. Commissioner of Income- tax  3 , does not apply to this case because this is not a case of an allocation of a sum out of revenue before it becomes income
We have, therefore, come to the conclusion that the High Court correctly answered the question referred to it.
